entry.title: Soviet Red Army Monument in Harbin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although the Soviet Red Army Monument in Harbin (pictured) was covered with scaffolding during the Sino-Soviet split, wreaths were still laid in front of it during the Qingming Festival and on Victory Day?

entry.title: women's 400 metres (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Femke Bol won the women's 400 metres and 400 metres hurdles at the 2022 European Athletics Championships in an unprecedented double victory?

entry.title: Vann Molyvann (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Cambodian architect Vann Molyvann declined a request from Lee Kuan Yew to help design Singapore?

entry.title: 2024 Rose Bowl (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Michigan and Alabama entered the 2024 Rose Bowl as the two college football teams with the most all-time wins?

entry.title: Wandering Souls (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the author of the novel Wandering Souls, about Vietnamese refugees, was inspired by an episode of A Very British History?

entry.title: Kim Ye-ji (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Kim Ye-ji's performance in the 10 meter air pistol at the 2024 Summer Olympics led her to be dubbed the "coolest person on the planet"?

entry.title: 1936 Summer Olympics, Liechtenstein (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that for the 1936 Summer Olympics, Liechtenstein flipped their flag upside down?

entry.title: co-wrote and co-produced her own (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after a British Sikh physician could not find any recent mainstream English film led by a woman that resembled her, she co-wrote and co-produced her own?

entry.title: Frederick Perceval, 11th Earl of Egmont (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Frederick Perceval, 11th Earl of Egmont, was nicknamed "the loneliest boy in the world" by journalists?
